129058259.review:
Southern Banana Bread

Ingredients:
    2¼ cups all-purpose flour, sifted
    1 cup sugar
    1 teaspoon baking soda
    1 teaspoon salt
    4 medium ripe bananas, mashed (about 1½ cups)
    ½ cup unsalted butter, melted and cooled
    2 large eggs
    1 teaspoon vanilla extract

Directions:
-Preheat oven to 325°. Spray a 9×5-inch loaf pan with baking spray with flour.
-In a large bowl, whisk together flour, sugar, baking soda, and salt. In a medium bowl, whisk together banana, melted butter, eggs, and vanilla. Fold banana mixture into flour mixture until just combined. Spread batter into prepared pan.
-Bake until a wooden pick inserted in center comes out clean, 50 to 60 minutes. Let cool in pan for 10 minutes. Remove from pan, and let cool completely on a wire rack. Store in an airtight container for up to 3 days.

135506762.review:
As I sit here, amidst the chaos and carnage of the zombie apocalypse, I cannot help but feel a sense of exhilaration and satisfaction that can only come from playing Left 4 Dead 2. This game, my friends, is a true masterpiece - a magnum opus of undead-slaying madness that has forever changed the way we view zombie games.

From the moment I started, I was hooked. The graphics, the sound, the gameplay - it all came together in a symphony of blood, guts, and glory that left me breathless. The attention to detail is simply unparalleled - every zombie, every weapon, every level is crafted with a precision and care that can only come from a team of dedicated professionals who truly love what they do.

But what sets Left 4 Dead 2 apart from other zombie games is the sheer intensity of the experience. The hordes of undead that come at you from all directions, the heart-stopping crescendo events, the adrenaline-fueled escapes - it all adds up to a thrill ride unlike anything else in gaming. And let's not forget the special infected - the jockey, the smoker, the hunter - each one a unique and terrifying threat that keeps you on your toes and constantly on the lookout for danger.

But perhaps the greatest aspect of Left 4 Dead 2 is its cooperative gameplay. This is a game that truly shines when played with friends - the teamwork, the coordination, the sheer joy of surviving together against all odds. And with so many different game modes and levels to choose from, the replay value is off the charts.

Left 4 Dead 2 is simply the best zombie game ever made. It is a masterpiece of gaming that combines stunning visuals, pulse-pounding action, and cooperative gameplay to create an experience that is both thrilling and unforgettable. If you haven't played it yet, do yourself a favour and join the fight against the undead - you won't regret it.

138159254.review:
Left 4 Dead 2 is genius in the way that it puts true teamplay above overpowering players like you see in various other multiplayer titles. The special infected act as a handicap for the player, which creates a real sense of dependency: you must rely on your teammates to help you out in any predicament. The friendly fire strongly encourages players to place their shots carefully and to not mindlessly play the game.

Level design is top notch with incredible environmental storytelling, pretty open spaces, and the survival horror elements provide incentive for exploration. The physical interactivity of the environment makes any encounter with infected visually impressive and satisfying. 

The lack of skill trees, progression, etc. makes Left 4 Dead 2 incredibly timeless, as you can hop back into the game ten years from now and play at no disadvantage to other players. The skills and strategies you learn will stay with you by the time you return to the game in ten years. Simplicity is a strength of Left 4 Dead 2's gameplay. 

The pacing of the action is expertly done, allowing the players to enjoy moments of respite after a sudden horde. The game knows how to keep the moment to moment gameplay from feeling repetitive. The moments of respite also serve as opportunities for exploration, which is great. A multiplayer game that balances the action and the exploration is simply fantastic. The game is at its best when the audio cues suggest to the players that a horde is coming, and everyone scrambles to find a spot to hold up in and prepare for the onslaught, building tension as players await their possible demise.

137334082.review:
The principle is simple, but perfectly functional. A team of four cooperates against hordes of infected. Basic zombies aren't dangerous in themselves, but they make up for this handicap with numbers.
Far more dangerous are more capable individuals, who tend to jump on players, throw up, or attract them with their tongue several meters long.

It is in the cooperation of the players that the main strength lies. It pays to stick together and help each other when needed. That includes the situation where your species is rolling on the ground and has a few last moments left before it dies completely. That's when you should rush to the rescue and lift him, at least temporarily, to his feet.
Other types of team solidarity include healing allies or passing out pain pills that temporarily increase health.

As unbelievable as it sounds, in conjunction with the quality game modes, this system has ensured tremendous playability. The first episode already showed it, and the sequel is no exception. The frenetic and sometimes dull action will serve as a great release, and on the other hand, as more serious entertainment. [b] 20% [/b]

The variety of maps, levels and characters add to the replayability factor, giving players hours of enjoyment. The game's core concept of co-op team gameplay adds a whole new dimension to the zombie survival genre, making it a must-play for horror and FPS gaming enthusiasts alike. Additionally, the game has a fantastic online community aspect that keeps players engaged and connected even after completing the story mode. Overall, I highly recommend Left 4 Dead 2 to anyone looking for a challenging, heart-pumping adventure. a game to the undead.

144787932.review:
L4D2 is an amazingly well crafted game which still holds up today in 2023. I have put in about 130 hours within the span of a month. I do not regret any of the time I spent. Its even more enjoyable when you have people to play with and even repeating the campaigns can be fun with friends. 

Versus is one of the most fun pvp gameplay modes I have ever experienced. The main thing limiting it is the toxic lobbies which are about half the time. Its also more common for new players due to many older players not having the patience to understand that new players will not pick up all the lingo in a day, same as them when they started. I would highly recommend playing versus, but do not let the toxic players get to you and try to play with friends. 

As for an achievement run, its a good experience and there are really only 2-3 nearly impossible achievements which include a christmas achievement in versus, a free weekend achievement which seems to only happen every few years, and an achievement to play with someone who got the game for free in 2013. Besides this every achievement is completely possible in 2023 and are either incredibly easy to get or may at the very most just require some workshop content (mutations help a lot too for some). I cheesed as little as possible but for example the gold survival medals on all 43 maps is a little tedious without Raymans horde mode. This is because survival is not a fun experience especially when you are alone since there are fewer players, survival players mainly just play a small handful of the total maps, and then you have to also make it to 10 mins which without hordes is a task and a half to do unless you're some survival pro. 

All in all 9.5/10, would highly recommend!

138619610.review:
I am a 50 year old human male, probably one of the oldest and most boring people playing this game. I am a father to my 15 children, ranging from ages 3 to 40. My 37 year old son recently started Left 4 Dead 2 and in less than a week, he had already played for over 200 hours. This was amazing for me, as it was already hard enough for me to avoid spending time with my insufferable offspring. All they care for these days is recording them TikTok dances, collecting Funko Pops and scrolling Instagram.

Inspired by seeing him having a reason to stop coming out of the basement to ask for more junk food, I decided to try it myself. I loaded into the game, smashed some buttons but I was stuck on what I was supposed to do. I asked my son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. As soon as we loaded in, he immediately started shouting unintelligible commands at me through his rainbow flashing headset like "CAMP THE SPAWN!" and "POP SOME PILLS AND MOLLY THAT TANK!" Every time I messed up, which was always, he would call me names like noob and filthy casual.

The horde of zombies descending upon our characters was reminiscent of the swarm of children I had unwittingly spawned into this world. I have never felt more confused and upset in my decades of fatherhood. This was the worst time I had spent with my son since his mother had that mid-life crisis.

This game has ever since driven my son and I apart again and now we actually spend even less time together. This game reminded me that there's misery to be had in everything, and it has brought me many traumatic memories of my failed attempts at fatherhood.

131098114.review:
Here we are roughly one year after the release of Left 4 Dead, and its sequel is already out. For Valve, Left 4 Dead 2 represents an unusually speedy turnaround time considering the delays and release date fuzziness generally associated with its games, notably in the years leading up to Team Fortress 2 and the still mysterious status of Half-Life 2: Episode 3. Despite that history and the potential concerns associated with how soon this game is showing up after the first, Left 4 Dead 2 is very much a complete game, much more so than the original, and is without a doubt the better product. If you're still in the mood to group up with friends and slay packs of ravenous undead, then it doesn't get any better than this. However, if you're tired of Left 4 Dead's gameplay formula, the sequel, as good as it is, may not be enough to warrant a purchase. It's a game that's more about refinement and augmentation of existing features instead of offering something dramatically new.

As a result, after you've played Left 4 Dead 2, it's difficult to go back to the original without a mild sense of disappointment. Remember, of Left 4 Dead's four original campaigns, only two were set up for Versus play right out of the gate. It wasn't until Valve released the Survival Pack months later that players got the full Versus experience as well as the now-standard timed Survival mode. Left 4 Dead 2 has five full and more interesting campaigns, a more fleshed out and distinctive setting with some fantastic action set pieces, more personality, more modes, and in general gives you more to do. In many ways, I wish this would have been the product that was released first since it feels much more full-featured than the original, and the fiercely team-oriented style of gameplay wouldn't have been as familiar then as it is now.

It's entirely possible you're someone who never played the first and have no idea what I'm talking about, so I'll take a step back for a moment. It's the zombie apocalypse, and you play as one of four human Survivors who attempt to shoot their way through hordes of fast-moving "infected" (which I'll refer to as zombies) to get to the end of a map. The sequel is set in the American southeast and the new cast of characters is more memorable this time around, as they seem more aware of their situation, chattering away and commenting on specific parts of the environment as they battle through. Ellis' inane stories while huddled in safe houses are a particular highlight as he waxes on about accident-prone acquaintances while mobs of bloodthirsty zombies converge on his position, at which point the others understandably tell him to shut his mouth.


That's not what you should be doing while playing, however. More effectively than most other titles out there, Left 4 Dead 2 forces you to work as a team if you want to win. You need to talk, and you need to participate. Every member of your four person squad of Survivors needs to be communicating about what they're doing, calling out locations for ammunition, weapon, and health pickups, and asking for help when in trouble. The catch is that no stage ever plays out the same way, because there's an artificial intelligence called the Director governing the action. Packs of common zombies can attack at any time, and if what the Director throws at you proves too challenging, your path of progression through a stage may even get swapped around to make things easier. It makes every experience different, and encourages repeat play as it adapts to challenge players of any skill level.


MORE ZOMBIE TYPES MAKE THE GAMEPLAY EVEN MORE UNPREDICTABLE.

Like before, there are multiple difficulty settings, with Normal serving as a good entry-level challenge while on Expert only those with the best communication, decision-making, and reaction skills will survive. Left 4 Dead 2's Realism mode makes the challenge even more daunting, removing helpful glows around items and weapons amongst other things, meaning it's all up to your communication skills to call out ammunition and item pickups or to let people know you're in trouble. If you're the type of player who generally shies away from a conversation and prefers to remain silent, then you're not going to like Left 4 Dead, mostly because your team isn't going to do very well if everyone's only interacting on a minimal level. Because of how much teamwork is required in Left 4 Dead, it's also one of the best games out there for triggering an emotional response in players, which works both ways. If you manage to pull through, you feel a much greater sense of accomplishment, and if you're losing, it can be singularly frustrating since your success is just as reliant on the behavior of those around you as it is on your own personal skill.

Bots are still included, though, so if you do want to run through the five campaigns by yourself that's entirely possible, and should a person have to drop out midway through a campaign, an artificial intelligence will take over so you don't have to all give up. Your computer-controlled teammates will work alongside, making accurate shots, swapping out weapons, reviving, trading items and healing when necessary. It's nowhere close to as entertaining an experience, but it's still functional and playable solo. Ideally, like when preparing for a dungeon run in an MMO, you'll be able to get a full party together to tackle the challenges, and it's an experience that's at its best when in a full Versus game.

Versus is also where you'll be challenged the most, as four players will be running through as Survivors and four others controlling the powerful boss zombie types. These include the Tanks, Boomers, Smokers, and Hunters from the first game, in addition to the new Spitters, Jockeys, and Chargers. The new boss zombie special powers add layers to the gameplay, such as the Spitter's acid pool that can do heavy damage over time to anyone who stumbles into it. The Jockey's ability to take over control of a Survivor's direction of movement makes for even more interesting combination possibilities here, and overall the addition of these new boss zombies adds in a welcome amount of depth and, if you're playing as Survivors, unpredictability to the play experience. If your Infected team is working together you can time Boomer bile attacks with Jockey jumps and Spitter attacks so large groups of common zombies are attacking while one Survivor stumbles under a Jockey's control and the rest are slowly dying in a pool of acid.

These kinds of team tactics are subject to further refinement when you take into account the campaign-specific challenges, some of which are sure to get your pulse pounding. To be perfectly clear, this is not a relaxing game. You're tense and fixated on the screen at all moments, and during sequences like the rollercoaster race in the Dark Carnival campaign and the storming and flooding of the second half of Hard Rain, you'll need to pay even closer attention. The campaigns here include exciting crescendo events and defense sequences that any hardcore Left 4 Dead fan is going to go absolutely nuts over. In that sense, if you're still playing Left 4 Dead and are looking for more, then you're going to love this product.

It's not just the better campaigns, the more fully-realized and detailed environments and the switch from the dark city streets of the first game to the bogs, carnival grounds, marshes, and sunlit construction yards that contribute to reasons why this is a better game. There's also a wealth of little things that make this a sturdier, more complex, and more entertaining experience. You'll find scattered around rooms incendiary and explosive ammunition pickups for all to enjoy, a wider range of rifles, submachine guns, shotguns, and sniper rifles to pick apart your opposition (though many of the like weapons models behave similarly), and perhaps most importantly of all, in Left 4 Dead 2 you can take advantage of melee weapons.

137393219.review:
-Left 4 Dead 2 is a hilarious and action-packed game that will have you laughing and screaming in equal measure. Developed and published by Valve Corporation, the game features hordes of zombies and other creatures that players must fight their way through in order to survive.

-What I love about this game is how it encourages teamwork and communication, something that most gamers are not exactly known for. If you're not communicating with your fellow survivors, you're going to end up as zombie chow. And trust me, there's nothing worse than being eaten alive while your teammates are busy looting the nearest convenience store.

-The graphics and sound design are top-notch, but what really sets Left 4 Dead 2 apart is its sense of humor. The game is filled with hilarious one-liners and pop culture references, such as when Coach, one of the playable characters, says "I'm gonna mess up some zombies like it's prom night!" How can you not laugh at that?

-One downside of the game is that it can get a bit repetitive after a while. Fighting through waves of zombies can start to feel like a chore after a few hours of gameplay. However, the dynamic AI Director helps to keep things fresh by adjusting the difficulty level based on how well the players are doing.

-Overall, if you're looking for a fun and funny game to play with your friends, then I would definitely recommend giving Left 4 Dead 2 a try. Just be prepared to laugh until you cry, or until a zombie eats your face off. Whichever comes first.

Very scari game. But if you are looking for easy fried rice recipe you're in the right place!




Ingredients
⅔ cup chopped baby carrots

½ cup frozen green peas

2 tablespoons vegetable oil

1 clove garlic, minced, or to taste (Optional)

2 large eggs

3 cups leftover cooked white rice

1 tablespoon soy sauce, or more to taste

2 teaspoons sesame oil, or to taste

Directions:
Step 1
Assemble Ingredients.

Step 2
Place carrots in a small saucepan and cover with water. Bring to a low boil and cook for 3 to 5 minutes. Stir in peas, then immediately drain in a colander.

Step 3
Heat a wok over high heat. Pour in vegetable oil, then stir in carrots, peas, and garlic; cook for about 30 seconds. Add eggs; stir quickly to scramble eggs with vegetables.

Step 4 
Stir in cooked rice. Add soy sauce and toss rice to coat. Drizzle with sesame oil and toss again.

Step 5 
Serve hot and enjoy!

Oh, you're actually gonna read my rambling review? :o Well thank you. I will be blunt and honest. Its never gone badly for me before, heh... :/

*Look at me, I'm a speedrunner! Watch me rush! Trust me guys, I... Oh, revive me, I got rayg- 'You have been kicked.'*

Let me start this off by saying something. Its not for solo play. if you don't like dealing with or working with others, you're NOT gonna like this. You wanna go lone wolf, or go Rambo? Then you'll get carved by a Hunter like you are a suckling pig at a Pegan banquet, or worse, learn why the Jockey is considered the contribution by Valve to ruining everyone's day. That said, alot of people say if you have no friends, don't bother either. Well, this is a good place to make some! :D

You can get decent pick up groups and randos for this game, in all honesty 80% are kind, patient, and have a good sense of humor and fair skills. And the other 18%, are at least civil and acceptable. But the 2%, that's the bad apples that spoils the bunch. That's the fly in the ointment of this game. Block those people, and try to 'collect' people as I do, ones that are fun and cooperative, and you should be fine. Just do not expect a flawless cruise. But, moving on from that?

*Look out! Weebery ahead! Mods galore!*
It's very, very fun. Holds up far better then any 13 year old game should. And Its not so much Valve's support (More on that soon enough, I need to grind that axe to a fine edge....) that has kept the game thriving, that's the dedicated playerbase. THOUSANDS, of mods and addons on the Workshop, have had people always coming back, all the wonders, and horrors you can imagine await your perusal.

Want weeb trash anime characters replacing your survivors? Hold onto your pocky, there is a flood of that for ya. Are you a perv? Holy Rule 34, you're all set there amigo. >.> Or maybe you just wanna have chaos. Shrek Tanks, Sanic Hunters, Gabe Boomers, kittens as the commons...? Todd Howard Witches, Teletubbies as commons, Mountain Dew as pills, Windows start up noises for the defib? Let it be done. Maybe something respectable, practical even? HD reworks, enhancements, new weapons, new maps, with scripts even? Psh, normie. But you're set there too. People will dazzle and impress you with their modding skills with all you can hope for. Just be wary, not all test their mods or put in due effort, and some mods really do not play well with others, so test thoroughly in single player before going out in the wild.

*It's an older game sir, but it checks out... I was about to play it.*

Lets see, what else to note... The games old, even with the Last Stand update (An officially supported add on for a game over 10 years old!? I know, and its great, I love it, people just hate it cause it disrupted a TON of mods...) So any potato rig should be able to run it if you don't overstuff it with mods like a kid unattended at Build a Bear. But lets get into the nitty gritty, brass tacks and all. Lets be honest, the game is lovely, but it has its flaws.

As stated from the outset, its not just the bad eggs you are wanting to not play the game solo for, its the bots. The AI controlled survivors. They are mind-numbingly incompetent, truly a marvel of how not to program. Watch any compilation on Youtube and you'll easily see what I mean. Misuse of healing supplies, lack of prioritization when healing or assisting you, or even each other, and their slow clumsy attempts to evade a tank, or god forbid freeing you from a Jockey or a Smoker in a timely manner, critical during horde events or on expert where 1-2 tics of damage mean ALOT.

Its not all bad, seeing as how they have magic bullets incapable of friendly fire, are immune to bile blindness, able to revive you even when you are getting mob rushed and stomped on like a Youtube comment section, (That is when they get around to helping you up and not letting themselves be an easy target for any enterprising special infected) they are even able to kill infected you cannot see, often in trees or behind cover. They also are unable to startle witches with gunfire, in a blatant showing of favoritism on her part I might add, or start evadable events like car alarms. For these reasons, 1 bot is actually rather helpful, if you geniuses can pick up its slack.

*You were the chosen one! It was said you would support the game, not leave it in darkness! You were my brother Gaben, I loved you...*

Yeah, here it is, my gripefest. Strap yourselves in, excess sodium incoming. Besides giving modders and fans their blessing by allowing an update, Valve has been like a father who tried at first, then left for some milk and never came back, besides now and then scratching up a check for alimony that you aren't sure will bounce or not. The official addons for the games, vary in quality, The Passing and Sacrifice being good, And Crash Course being... Not. And all are a bit short, 2-3 chapters in length. If you play on expert you might get your moneys worth (Just an expression, this game is like 5, maybe 10 dollars usually, and the DLC has always been free, except on Xbox, poor devils) but most clear them fast and hunger for more. And a quick tangent, Xbox Players really got the stiff one here, no last stand update? No fixes that we managed to get, no new weapons, no new campaign, no new unused dialogue? What a crock of crap. For shame, Valve. Way to make those Console Peasants feel second class.

Its been said they were designed for more intensive Versus play, but some like myself don't like Versus. it's honestly where alot of negativity in this game stems from. Disgusting sprays, toxic and downright elitest behavior, tons of unwritten rules and expectations, I am sure most are kind and just wanna play a fun game, but most the antics and vile conduct and content, is there.

Besides some... debatable effort offered in the DLCs, there is evidence to this day of Valve's unfortunate abandonment of their game. Annoying bugs left for years for their fans to fix, some are just in the very framework and engine itself. And mind boggling lack of foresight, such as why can't I BLOCK PEOPLE FROM JOINING MY GAME!? Good god, why can't I do that? People can jump, over, and over, and OVER, into your game that you kick out. There is no 3 strike rule, there is no 'kicked from this game, no entry' check. Nothing. It's insanity, even in the developmental commentary they stated you can walk through survivors partially to avoid griefing, yet they didn't think there would be teamkillers or jerks and have a solid way to keep them kicked out? That's idiotic nonsense, very incompetent and unprofessional of a ground breaking studio with 10+ years of excellent games at the time of its release, and the fact to this day there is no recourse short of a private server, is even more insulting.

So yeah, games good, not perfect, but great stuff.

The sequel lets you play as another group of four survivors who are different from its prequel.It has far more extra game modes compared to its prequel with more choice of weapons and new special infected.All the L4D1 campaigns are included in this game with some atmospheric changes and the new special infected are also present in the old campaign along with the new weapons and improved graphics making the gameplay better than its prequel.

There is very less to no player base in few game modes and those achievements related to that game modes might be tough to do but can be done with custom workshop maps or by forming a team.

Overall, Left 4 Dead 2 has better player base and replayability value than its prequel with improvised gameplay .

146652328.review:
Title: "Left 4 Dead 2: Surviving the Zombie-pocalypse, One Laughter at a Time"

Left 4 Dead 2 is the game where you and your pals team up to fight off zombies while also accidentally setting each other on fire. It's like a horror movie directed by the Three Stooges – slapstick humor meets the undead.

Picture this: You're frantically trying to heal your friend, and instead, you throw a molotov cocktail in their face. Oops! In Left 4 Dead 2, teamwork is vital, but so is friendly fire. It's a delicate balance between "I've got your back!" and "Watch out, I've got a grenade launcher!"

From chainsaw massacres to hilariously bad attempts at survival, Left 4 Dead 2 turns the zombie apocalypse into a sidesplitting comedy of errors. So grab your cricket bat, duct-tape some defibrillators together, and get ready for some undead laughs – because in this game, the real monster is your friend with the grenade launcher!

137917506.review:
"Left 4 Dead 2 is the ultimate zombie apocalypse simulator. It's like The Walking Dead, but with more guns, more gore, and way more running.

As one of four survivors, you'll fight your way through hordes of undead while trying not to become a human Happy Meal. And if that sounds stressful, don't worry! You can always blow off some steam by shooting your teammates in the back.

But what really makes Left 4 Dead 2 special is the variety of zombie types. From the classic slow-moving zombies to the speedy "Witch" who will rip you to shreds, each enemy provides a unique challenge.

And let's not forget the special infected, like the spitter who pukes acid all over you, or the jockey who jumps on your head and steers you into danger. These guys are like the Kardashians of the zombie world – you don't want to mess with them.

Overall, Left 4 Dead 2 is a fun, fast-paced shooter that will keep you on the edge of your seat (or your couch, if you're playing on console). Just don't forget to bring some friends, because no one wants to face the zombie apocalypse alone. Plus, you'll need someone to blame when you get pounced on by a hunter."

133954092.review:
[h1] It would be dumb to buy Back 4 Blood over this.[/h1]
[b] Little Rant [/b]
[i] According to recent news, Back 4 Blood will no longer be producing new content in 2023 and its future. Despite the involvement of Left 4 Dead developers from Turtle Rock Studios, the game has not lived up to expectations and has fallen short. On the other hand, Left 4 Dead 2 has been around for 14 years and continues to be popular and engaging, thanks in part to its active Steam Workshop community. Rant aside, If you prefer Back 4 Blood, that's fine, but Left 4 Dead 2 offers a more comprehensive gaming experience at a more affordable price point ($15 AUD compared to $90 AUD).[/i]

[h2] Actual Review [/h2]
Left 4 Dead 2 is a cooperative first-person shooter game that offers players an immersive and challenging gaming experience. The game is set in a post-apocalyptic world where a zombie outbreak has occurred, and players take on the role of one of four survivors, each with their own unique abilities and personalities.

[h2] Pros and cons [/h2]
[table]
[tr]
[th] 🟩 Positives [/th]
[th] 🟥 Negatives [/th]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td]
- Engaging gameplay that is easy to pick up but hard to master

- Distinctive art style that has aged well over time

- Diverse range of special zombie types that add extra challenge and excitement to gameplay

- Extensive Steam Workshop content that ensures there is always something new to experience

- Strong AI that adapts to players' strategies and keeps the game feeling fresh
	[/td]
	[td]
- Can be frustrating to play with uncooperative or inexperienced teammates

- Limited replayability for players who are not interested in using the Steam Workshop content

- [i] It gets lonely when you have no friends ;( [/i]
	[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]	

[h2] Story [/h2]
In terms of story, Left 4 Dead 2 doesn't have a strong narrative, and the story is mostly told through the game's environments and characters rather than cutscenes or dialogue. However, the game's setting and atmosphere are well done and make the player feel like they are actually in a zombie outbreak.

[h2] Gameplay [/h2]
One of the key elements of the game's combat is the variety of zombies that players must face. The game includes a number of special infected, such as the Boomer, the Hunter, and the Smoker, each of which requires unique tactics to take down. This keeps the game challenging and requires players to think critically about how to approach each situation, making the game a real test of teamwork and strategic thinking.

The game features a wide range of firearms, from pistols to shotguns, as well as melee weapons like pipes and axes. Additionally, players can use environmental objects, such as propane tanks or gasoline cans, as improvised weapons to help fend off the zombies.

Another key aspect of Left 4 Dead 2's gameplay is its artificial intelligence Director, which adjusts the gameplay for each playthrough, keeping the game challenging and replayable. The Director ensures that players never experience the same game twice, providing a unique experience each time they play. The AI Director also keeps the difficulty level high, providing players with a real sense of danger and urgency as they fight their way through the hordes of zombies.

[h3] Steam Workshop [/h3]
The Steam Workshop is an essential part of the game's longevity, as it provides players with new and creative content that helps to keep the game fresh and engaging. It also fosters a strong community of players who are passionate about the game, and it provides a platform for players to collaborate and share their ideas. By providing an endless stream of new and creative content, the Steam Workshop helps to ensure that Left 4 Dead 2 remains a popular and enjoyable game for years to come.

[h2] Audio Design [/h2]
One aspect of the game that greatly contributes to player immersion is the use of musical cues when the special infected are nearby. These music cues serve as audio cues that help to alert players to the presence of the enemy and increase their sense of danger and urgency.

The musical cues are unique and memorable, and they are tailored specifically to each special infected. For example, the Hunter's music cue is fast-paced and intense, conveying the urgency of the situation and the danger posed by the Hunter. On the other hand, the Boomer's music cue is slow and ominous, building tension and suspense as the Boomer prepares to attack. These music cues are distinct and recognizable, even when playing with others, and they help to make each special infected feel like a unique and dangerous enemy.

The use of music cues in Left 4 Dead 2 is a critical aspect of the game's audio design, and it plays a significant role in enhancing player immersion. By providing audio cues that are easy to recognize, the game helps to increase player engagement and build a more immersive and believable game world. The music cues also help to increase the sense of tension and urgency, adding to the overall challenge and excitement of the game.

[h2] Conclusion [/h2]
In conclusion, Left 4 Dead 2 is an absolute must-play for fans of the cooperative shooter genre. The game's engaging story, immersive combat, and distinct art style make it a timeless classic that continues to captivate players more than a decade after its initial release. Its extensive Steam Workshop content ensures that there is always something new to experience, making it a game that can be played and enjoyed for years to come. While the game does have its flaws, such as its lack of campaign variety and occasional bugs, these are minor in the grand scheme of things. 

Overall, Left 4 Dead 2 is a highly recommended title that is well worth its affordable price tag and a must-play for anyone who enjoys cooperative shooters.

145896251.review:
Left 4 Dead 2 (L4D2) is worth buying for several reasons:

1. Cooperative Gameplay: L4D2 is renowned for its cooperative multiplayer gameplay. You team up with friends or AI-controlled characters to survive hordes of zombies. The synergy between players is crucial for success, making it a great choice for cooperative gaming.

2. Replayability: The game offers a variety of campaigns, maps, and game modes. Each playthrough is different due to the AI Director, which dynamically adjusts the difficulty and item placement, ensuring every session feels fresh.

3. Mod Support: L4D2 has an active modding community that continually creates new maps, characters, weapons, and game modes. This extends the game's lifespan and provides endless content possibilities.

4. Intense Action: The game delivers adrenaline-pumping action, as you face waves of zombies and special infected with unique abilities, creating a constant sense of urgency and excitement.

5. Community and Multiplayer: L4D2 has a dedicated player base, which means you can easily find others to play with online. Whether you enjoy cooperative or competitive modes, there's something for everyone.

6. Cross-Platform Play: As of my last update in September 2021, L4D2 introduced cross-platform play, allowing players on different systems to join forces or compete.

7. Classic Title: L4D2 is considered a classic in the zombie survival genre, and its longevity and popularity attest to its enduring appeal.

Ultimately, Left 4 Dead 2 offers an immersive, cooperative, and highly replayable gaming experience that is well worth the investment, especially if you enjoy intense multiplayer action and zombie-themed games.

134911549.review:
Left 4 Dead 2 The Legendary Co-Op Game

One of the best co-op games ever made, this game nails everything it has to offer. Having a handful of interesting and well-designed maps, 8 cool characters, with a great weapons variety, this game never fails to entertain the player. Combine all these with the community mods, the content of this game is endless, there are lots of add-on maps, weapon skins and tons of other mods that can be downloaded for free, and will give this game a refreshing feel. There are a bunch of different game modes to entertain different types of players, campaign, versus, survival, etc. Which are all fun and entertaining. Comparing to the first game, there are more death animations for zombies, the AI is drastically improved and there are new enemy types. The attention to details is what gives this game a soul. There are a few things that have been downgraded from the first game, like the infinite shove, they nerfed shoving and gave it a cool down to justify the existence of melee weapons, which is not necessarily a bad thing, the first game has 2 different reload animations for guns but they reduced it to 1 in the second game. But these are negligible and can be fixed with mods.

If you are looking for a co-op game to play with friends with infinite amount of content and you love zombie games, this is the perfect game for you.

131095419.review:
Left 4 Dead 2 might actually be Valve's best game, and that's a massive high water mark. Half-Life and its sequels, the Portal duology, and Counter-Strike are absolutely revolutionary games that shook up the status quo for first-person shooters. The original Left 4 Dead was a must-buy when it came out. Against all odds, L4D2 stands above them all as a lovingly crafted, extremely replayable, and immensely enjoyable shooter. It's such a good cooperative experience that it inspired later games like Payday: The Heist and Back 4 Blood!

Left 4 Dead 2 is a co-op zombie FPS that pits you and 3 other friends against hordes of the Infected, mutated humans warped by a strange disease called the "Green Flu." The plot is split between 4 survivors in Pennsylvania and 4 others in the American South, with each campaign telling a unique story of fighting through the Infected to (potentially) reach safety. This ranges from navigating to the top of an overrun city's hospital to trying to signal an evacuation chopper in an amusement park. Every character stands out with a distinct personality and quirks, like Louis's optimism or Nick's suspicion of everything around him. A lot of storytelling is done through in-game graffiti, implied events, and smaller details you might miss in one playthrough. The sheer amount of survivor dialogue for each situation ensures that every playthrough will feel slightly different than another.

Combat in L4D2 is very rewarding and intense. You can carry a primary weapon, a sidearm/melee weapon, a throwable, and two medical items. Your typical FPS guns are here, but they're punchy and feel powerful. The dismemberment system for enemies really drives home how deadly your attacks can be. Rifle rounds can blast limbs off of the Infected, shotgun blasts tear them to pieces, and explosives reduce them to piles of body parts. Common Infected enemies will swarm you and slow you down with their hits, but the real threats come from the Special Infected. Each one has a musical cue to signal its arrival and can hamper your team with their abilities. Spitters launch acidic bile that blankets the ground and damages you, Hunters can leap long distances and pounce on you, and Tanks turn ordinary gunfights into chaotic boss battles with their huge health total and powerful attacks.

RNG elements are present in how campaigns operate, primarily driven by the game's AI Director. This affects the placement of Infected, locations of items, and sometimes even the level design itself! You might get lucky and find some laser sights to enhance your gun's accuracy in one run, while in another you might find a bottle of pills in the same spot. A shortcut to the bumper cars might be open in Dark Carnival, or you might have to take a slightly longer way around. The Witch, a docile infected that instantly downs you when provoked enough, could be in any number of places - some of which might directly get in your way. Small and large scale changes like these keep you from getting too used to the way a certain campaign plays.

L4D2 also has a wide variety of modes to offer. Aside from the campaigns (single player or co-op), there are competitive modes like Versus (where one side plays as the Special Infected and the others as the Survivors) and Scavenge (where Survivors fill up a generator while the Special Infected try to stop them). There is also a Survival mode where you hold out as long as possible against an unending horde...as well as Versus Survival, where 4 Special Infected players can mess with 4 Survivor players trying to stand their ground. On top of that, there are Mutations that introduce unique game mechanics to campaigns, a Realism mode that nerfs the Survivors and encourages greater communication to survive, and Developer Commentary sections for some of the maps.

It's a game jam-packed full of content that feels fully realized and fleshed-out, and that isn't even starting on the mod support! L4D2 allows you to play custom campaigns and Survival levels made by the community, such as the surreal [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2257961887]Time to Die[/url] and the action-packed [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=128428201]Suicide Blitz 2.[/url] The game goes one step beyond and allows you to alter so much of its content, from the appearances of characters to various sounds to gameplay-altering scripts. Part of the replayability comes from being able to rework the visuals and audio so heavily. You could have TF2 characters wielding CS:GO weapons and fighting zombies from Call of Duty: World at War, and that's just one example of how bizarre the modded game can become.

No game is perfect, though, and L4D2 does have some minor flaws that deserve to be addressed:
-The bots aren't always the best at helping you, even with improvement mods active.
-The survivors from the first games don't have a ton of new lines for the sequel's content, resulting in them saying generic things when pointing out ammo upgrades or melee weapons.
-The difficulty gap between Advanced and Expert is huge, with Common Infected going from dealing 5 damage per hit to 20 damage per hit.
-Some melee weapons just feel worse than others, like the Pitchfork's narrow attack range or the Knife's strange swinging arc.
-The bolt-action sniper rifles are lumped together with the Tier 2 weapons when they would fit better in the less-effective Tier 1 selection.
-The standard Versus Mode is strongly biased in favor of the Survivors, which means that they'll usually escape a map unless the players are incompetent or the Special Infected can simultaneously incapacitate all of them.
-A couple of campaigns overdo it with the "unending horde" event leading up to a map's end, Cold Stream standing out with almost [i]every[/i] level having that scenario.

The survivor interactions, the enemy variety in campaigns, the thrilling combat, the musical direction - it all comes together to create this masterpiece of a co-op shooter. I can't recommend it enough, especially since its price is reasonable and it often goes on sale. The more you learn about L4D2's mechanics, the more you appreciate the hard work and detail put into the game. Although I would recommend starting the game without any mods to get used to it, I would strongly suggest using the improvement mods [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2238957546]Correct Campaign Order,[/url] [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=121094109]CrazyRabbit's Tactical Flashlight,[/url] and [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2165823958]Remove Explosion Flash.[/url] These small mods will go a long way to making Left 4 Dead 2 accessible, easy to pick up, and free of some in-game annoyances. With or without mods, though, L4D2 ranks high for me as Valve's best game. It truly deserves the honor!

127699313.review:
Держите рецепт торта муравейник

Продукты (на 8 порций)
Для теста:
Маргарин - 250 г
Сахар - 0,5 стакана
Яйца - 2 шт.
Сода - на кончике ножа
Соль - 1 щепотка
Мука - 400-500 г
Для крема:
Молоко сгущенное - 1 банка
Масло сливочное - 200 г

шаг №1
Подготовить продукты для приготовления "Муравейника".
Сгущенное молоко варить 1 час.

шаг №2
Как приготовить торт "Муравейник":
Яйца взбить вилкой.

шаг №3
Маргарин (масло) взбить с сахаром до получения пышной сметаноподобной массы.

шаг №4
Не переставая перемешивать деревянной ложкой (или обычной вилкой), добавить яйца, предварительно взбитые вилкой, соду, соль.

шаг №5
Постепенно всыпать муку.

шаг №6
Всыпать муки столько, чтобы после замеса получилось достаточно крутое тесто.
Поместите тесто в холодильник на 1 час.

шаг №7
Включить духовку.
Охлажденное в холодильнике тесто (60-65 мин) пропустить через мясорубку или натереть на терке.

шаг №8
Противень застелить пергаментом и смазать маслом.
Выложить в один слой разделенные жгуты теста на смазанный противень и выпекать при 150—170°С до зарумянивания (20-25 минут).

шаг №9
Для крема сливочное масло взбить до получения пышной массы.

шаг №10
Не переставая взбивать, малыми порциями добавить проваренное коричневато-бежеватого цвета сгущенное молоко.

шаг №11
Охлажденные после выпечки жгуты поломать на кусочки и хорошо перемешать с кремом.

шаг №12
Уложить на блюдо в виде горки и поставить торт "Муравейник" в холодильник.

Охлажденный и пропитавшийся торт "Муравейник" можно подавать. Приятного аппетита!

This game has cost me 1,000+ dollars, A month ago, at the time of this review, I was trying to take my computer back in time by reverting to an earlier state because I had messed something up in my game files. However due to my computer at the time being built in the year 2009 it could not handle it and after it restarted which took 2 hours, when it turned on it was very slow. Upon turning off the computer I got stuck in Windows Repair loop, and nothing worked. It always gave me an error message and would just send me back to the start of the loop. In frustration, I hit the side of my computer with a hammer, the computer made a *beep* sound which turned off the computer permanently. Since my car was broken I could not go to the store and buy one and had to wait until a friend of mine was free to go browse for computers which took about 1 1/2 weeks. During that time, I had entered pure isolation. I had not done anything meaningful to society as I was thinking about all of the Keith Stories i was missing out, all of the funny "Your mum's car" lines I was not hearing, and all the cheeseburgers coach would eat as he appears to be a very hungry individual. I had entered a deranged state at day 10, which I had devoted myself during that time to Prayer and Contemplation about life. At this point I did not need the computer, or any sort of technology, but rather I needed time away, I was free. The shackles of the internet were no longer leeched on to me, I had reached transcendence, possessing knowledge far beyond a layman's comprehension, I even wrote a little bit on how to solve problems that plague the world.. However, it all came crashing down. My friend called me soon afterwards about a computer, and I purchased it, blissfully unaware of the gnosis I was leaving behind. Left 4 Dead 2: the only game where team killing is not only allowed, but actively encouraged! And I have to say, some of my teammates take that encouragement to heart. But one guy in particular really stood out. Let's call him "Toxic Tom."

Toxic Tom was a real piece of work. He spent more time insulting our team and team killing than actually playing the game. And his favorite target? Yours truly. I mean, I get it - I'm a pretty easy target. But come on, man!

At one point, we were in the middle of a big zombie horde, trying to fight our way through to safety. I turn around to check on Tom, and what do I see? Him pointing his shotgun right at my face! I had no time to react before he pulled the trigger and sent me flying.

But here's the thing: I survived. And Tom didn't. That's right, folks - the toxic team killer got what was coming to him. Karma's a b*tch, Tom. Maybe next time you'll think twice before shooting your own teammates in the back.

In conclusion, Left 4 Dead 2 is a great game, but beware of Toxic Tom and his ilk. Play with friends if you can, or at least keep an eye out for any suspicious behavior. And remember, it's not just zombies you have to worry about - sometimes the real monsters are your own teammates!

142323006.review:
The pièce de résistance of horde shooters, Left 4 Dead 2 is masterfully done, and as a result, other games of the same genre simply struggle to impress in comparison. Ultimately this is a game of situational awareness, teamwork and gunplay in which four players face the AI director which determines the frequency of attacks, supplies and blocked off routes in one of the many campaign maps. This allows better players to be faced with more challenging experiences and likewise, newer players with more forgiving affairs. These variations in player experiences mean the game doesn't get stale compared to scripted events which are common in many other games, which greatly helps replayability.

On that topic, the game is workshop ready. Essentially any aesthetic changes you wish to make, you can. Feel like changing the four survivors to Dark Souls NPCs? Absolutely. My Little Ponies? Sure. My experience is modded for as much realism as the game can squeeze out, and of course all of it is free, which by todays standards is unheard of. 

The mechanics of the game are responsive and fluid, tried and tested on the source engine, which also means almost all PCs will run this well. The graphics are somewhat outdated, but not so much as to effect the player experience negatively in any way. And of course, the workshop can improve this aspect if you wish.

The 8 survivors available are for the most part, loveable, relatable and hilarious, and with a slew of interactions between them on top, you really end up liking most of the cast. Music is fairly well done in this game, while not being at the forefront of the player experience, there's clear thought put into its implementation. Certain musical cues will occur to alert the player that certain special enemies are close by.

Essentially the gameplay loop will consist of making your way from point A to point B across a campaign, consisting of a number of maps, concluding in a finale mission with a timed holdout situation (or other twists). Regular horde zombies stand in your way, acting as fodder to slow you down and overwhelm you while a selection of special enemies spawn periodically. These will typically incapacitate one of your team members, so looking out for one another is paramount. These synergies of special enemies become even more important in the Versus game mode, in which teams of four take turns playing as the infected. While considered a toxic element of the game, this mode is very fun. Perhaps I am biased as I've played this game for a very long time, so newer players may feel intimidated by this mode. There are a lot of newbie servers available however which I recommend.

All in all, I would consider this game to be a must own for any fan of zombies or team shooters. For the price, especially during sales, it's an absolute steal.

[b]Pros:[/b]
The quintessential horde shooter.
Smooth and responsive gameplay with excellent mechanics for survivors and infected.
Extensive workshop items to help customise your game experience.
AI director improves replayability.
Excellent value for money.

[b]Cons:[/b]
Versus can be problematic for newer players - recommended to find servers suitable for newbies.

Positives first.
Game is solid, campaigns are varied and has plenty of surprises to keep the game engaging, a real upgrade from L4D1, and is probably one of  the best Team Games that I highly recommend with friends. The game has value and can be worth the price.

But here's where the negatives come into play.
The biggest problem this game has is it's community, it is absolutely toxic 100% and if you don't have the stomach for it don't bother. You will get torn apart and most games turn into massive arguments over the simplest things, you will get kicked for the stupidest reasons before you can even finish a level, no one is wholesome or welcoming, everyone makes every attempt to post offensive and nasty comments ranging from simple bullying to outright racism and political, equipped with the most graphic of porn sprays, no one is ever happy even when winning a game, and if you aren't amazing at this game you will get branded the whole game regardless of the situation. Not to mention hackers and con artists who also break the game in two.

On the plus side, it also becomes a good grieving engine if you are into that, personally I have no qualms with grieving back when they start to get real nasty, but then again that could also lead to the side effect of adding to the problem so if you plan to do so, just be aware it can backfire badly for as much as it can be rewarding when done right.

Basically, the game is only good with friends, and I do mean ONLY good with friends, so unless you have the stomach for it, or you accept the way the community is, or if you are outright sadistic, I don't recommend online.

Overall, the game can be good, but the zombies are doing us a favour by eating up the horrible toxic community that play this game.

[ The Survivors walk past the motel on the highway while O Sweet Death plays. ]

[ Coach breaks through the boarded up door to a convenience store Safe Room in the park, unlocks it and everyone walks in. ]

Coach: Report unusual behavior...

[ Nick opens the cash register with his pistol and smirks. ]

Coach: Barricade your homes...

[ Ellis opens a gun cabinet and looks inside. His expression of bewilderment changes to a devilish smile. ]

Coach: Avoid all contact with infected individuals...

[ Rochelle is studying a map as Ellis places a pistol on top of it for her. She pushes it away as Ellis studies a Combat Shotgun. ]

[ Coach is shown reading off a piece of paper as he holds a chocolate bar. ]

Coach: Wait for official instructions. Heh, wait my ass!

[ Coach crumples the paper and throws it away as he walks towards the others eating his chocolate bar. Ellis has attached a grenade launcher, sniper rifle, a pipe bomb and first aid kit to his back. ]

Ellis: Kill all sons 'a bitches.

[ Ellis racks his Combat Shotgun. ]

Ellis: That's my 'ficial instructions.

[ Ellis kicks out the Safe Room door and they open fire on a group of Common Infected. Chocolate Helicopter begins to play.]

[ Coach punches an Infected in the face, knocking it down. Rochelle brings her axe into the face of a Common as Coach walks up to the downed Common. ]

Coach: This used to be a nice neighborhood!

[ Coach beats the Common's face in with the stock of his Chrome Shotgun. ]

[ Ellis and Nick run along the highway, when Ellis is tackled by a Jockey. Nick turns around.]

Nick: Shit!

[ Nick fires. Cut to the downed plane in the crash site. ]

Rochelle: What the hell was that?

[ A trio of mud men notice them and charge. ]

Ellis: Hey watch out!

[ Cut to Ellis and Rochelle hiding behind a fallen tree. Rochelle hushes Ellis as a Spitter appears on the other side of the tree. ]

Rochelle: Shhh... This is some grim shit we've got ourselves into...

[ The Spitter hacks up acid at the camera as the scene cuts to the Survivors fighting in the streets of Ducatel. ]

Rochelle: Get back! Get back!

[ Coach and Rochelle fire briefly at the horde before the Survivors run away. Ellis is helping Nick walk. Cut to the Survivors climbing a stairwell. ]

Coach: [ Panting from exhaustion ] Who the hell...puts an evac station...up thirty flights of goddamn stairs...

Nick: [ Exhausted ] Come on Сoach...maybe the helicopter...maybe it's made of chocolate. [ Chuckles ]

[ Coach scowls at Nick. ]

[ The Survivors reach the top of the building. Ellis is calling out. ]

Ellis: Hey where is everybody? Helloooo!

[ Four helicopters are seen flying away in the distance. ]

Rochelle: Ok, this is not happening...

Ellis: Anyone here?

Rochelle: ...This is not happening. This is not happening.

Coach: Aren't they supposed to be saving our asses?

Nick: Looks like there's been a change of plans.

[ Cut to jets bombing the embankment to the Louisiana Naval Shipyard, a Horde in the French Quarter, and a tractor trailer being blown into a group of Infected on the bridge. ]

Rochelle: [ Into a radio ] Stop the bombing run!

[ Cut to the Veterans Memorial Bridge collapsing into the river. ]

Radio voice: Jesus Christ! That's coming from the bridge!

[ Coach is thrown back onto the hood of a squad car as an explosion hits a gas tanker in front of him. Nick rushes over to help him. ]

Ellis: SHIT!

[ Nick looks up in surprise. ]

[ Ellis is attacked by a Charger in a burning shack. It roars, bursting through the wood, sending him flying. It then picks him up. ]

Ellis: It's got me!

[ The Charger pounds him on the ground. He grunts out loud. ]

[ Cut to Nick followed by a group of Infected climbing a roller coaster in Whispering Oaks. Nick is pulled up by Rochelle as a fireball engulfs the Infected. ]

Rochelle: Hang on!

[ Two hazmat suit Infected walk through flames and turn towards the camera. ]

[ The Survivors run down a hallway to an elevator. Ellis melees a Uncommon Riot Infected, but loses his Sniper Rifle to a Common Infected that trips with it's arms raised, making it fall out of his hands. He makes it inside the elevator, but a Smoker grabs him. ]

Ellis: Ah, what the hell-OWW!

[ Nick grabs onto Ellis, pulling him away from the infected as two Common Infected keep the doors open. Coach takes a chainsaw and decapitates the Infected and severs the Smoker's tongue. ]

Coach: Goddammit! Eat that shit!

[ Ellis collapses on the floor, and removes the tongue still wrapped around him. His expression of disgust turns to shock as he looks out the glass window, down at a swarm of Infected. ]

Ellis: Holy shit...

[ Coach helps Ellis to his feet as Rochelle hands him a grenade launcher. ]

Rochelle: Hey. "Kill all sons 'a bitches", right?

[ Ellis sheepishly nods, grinning at the grenade launcher. ]

[ The floor count changes from five to four. Cut to the Survivors on the stage of the Dark Carnival finale fighting a horde. Coach throws a gas can into the fireworks. ]

Coach: YEAH!

[ Ellis shoots the flying gas can with his Combat Rifle and it explodes above the horde of infected. ]

Nick (voiceover): I have not...

[ Floor count changes from 4 to 3. Rochelle cocks and fires a heavy machine gun from the porch of the mansion in Swamp Fever. ]

Nick (voiceover): ...come this far...

[ Floor count changes from 3 to 2. The Survivors are fighting a Tank on the Veteran's Memorial bridge. ]

Nick (voiceover): ...to die now.

[ Floor count changes from 2 to L. The doors of the elevator open up. As the Survivors prepare, Coach revs up his chainsaw to fight the horde. ]

in the late fall of 2009, volvo moved away from the manufacturing of motor vehicles to instead drop this absolute banger of a vidyagame. video games were new in 2009, as people were looking for new entertainment after the brutal economic downturn of 2008

as for the game itself, now that our historical context is established, this shit goes hard

you got four homies on your team

some coach guy
woman
and i dont remember the other two but they are more demographically appealing to the average gamer

this group of four must put forth collaborative effort to safely navigate the streets of detroit, memphis, or even new orleans. the locals are very accurately depicted to how they appear in real life, especially around the time of 2008's economic downturn

they approach in hordes and you handle that shit like you're RCMP about to run over protesters on horseback

this includes but is not limited to

exploding
burning them alive
projectile vomiting on as many people as possible
and generally bludgeoning them until they stop moving



a good 20/08, fun for the whole family and good for cardiovascular health

146236230.review:
As the sun dipped below the horizon, casting long shadows across your dimly lit room, you settled in for another night of gaming. Left 4 Dead 2 had been your go-to escape from the challenges of the real world. Tonight, however, would be different.

You fired up the game and joined a random online lobby, ready to face the infected hordes with your newfound team. The chatter of your teammates filled your headphones, a cacophony of voices from around the world united by a single purpose: survival.

You picked your favorite character, Ellis, and set off on a zombie-killing spree with your teammates. The adrenaline surged through your veins as you mowed down wave after wave of infected. But amidst the chaos and destruction, something felt off.

As the game progressed, you noticed that one of your teammates, a player named "LoneWolf92," seemed to be struggling. Their character lagged behind, missing shots and stumbling over obstacles. You tried to help, offering first aid kits and cover, but it seemed like something was wrong on their end.

LoneWolf92's voice came through your headset, shaky and filled with frustration. "Sorry, folks," they muttered, "I'm not doing so well tonight. Just go on without me."

Despite the urgency of the situation, you couldn't help but feel a pang of sympathy for LoneWolf92. Their struggles mirrored those in your own life—a feeling of being overwhelmed and left behind.

You and your remaining teammates forged ahead, pushing through the relentless onslaught of infected. The safe room was in sight, and victory seemed within reach. But as you turned back to see if LoneWolf92 had caught up, you realized they had disconnected from the game.

"Sorry, guys," you heard through your headphones as their voice trembled one last time. "I can't do this anymore. Goodbye."

The message was clear: LoneWolf92 had given up, not just on the game but perhaps on something deeper. You couldn't help but feel a sense of sadness as you continued to play, the thrill of victory tainted by the memory of a teammate who had, in that moment, lost their own battle.

As you logged off for the night and shut down your computer, you couldn't shake the melancholy feeling that had settled over you. Left 4 Dead 2 had always been an escape, but tonight, it had reminded you of the struggles and loneliness that could lurk just beneath the surface, even in the virtual world.

145864379.review:
Top 5 games of all time.

A formula that has had elements copied and ripped for over a decade. 
Influenced 15 years of coop and zombie games. 
Asymmetrical co-ops have worn marketed its inspiration clearly but failed to capture what made it so long lasting.
Iceberg of depth. The subtlety of environmental and interactive voice lines as you progress is game development mastery. 

Versus is timeless. Each infected has a skill ceiling that is subtle but rewarding to learn. hunter wall bouncing, tank rock curving. Game mechanics are simple enough to pick up but have nuance that keep you around if you like the competitiveness. If the punishing PvP isn't for you, still endless hours in custom maps that rival the originals! Polished third party content that is added to the game years later, Cold Stream for example. Tons of workshop support if you want to pimp your ride or just opt for sound and animation changes. 

Versus can be punishing to new players with how the vote kicking system works with low player counts but there's enough community involvement to find a home if you really want one, its just there with the late 2000s jank and you might to run in to some of the less agreeable source-game-enjoyer personalities.

144823930.review:
Review of the game "Left 4 Dead 2"

"Left 4 Dead 2" is a famous co-op first-person shooter game developed and published by Valve. The game was released in 2009 and became a real hit in the zombie apocalypse genre.

The gameplay of "Left 4 Dead 2" is based on team play, where you will fight together with three other players to survive in a dangerous world overrun by zombies. The game offers a variety of settings, such as city streets, abandoned cities, swamps and other locations full of dangers and bloodthirsty zombies.

One of the main advantages of "Left 4 Dead 2" is its intensity and dynamism. Zombies are coming at you from all sides, and you must make quick decisions, fight the hordes of enemies and stay safe. The game features different types of zombies, each with their own characteristics and threat to your team. Additionally, Left 4 Dead 2 offers a wide variety of weapons including rifles, shotguns, katanas and more to help you deal with the zombie invasion.

One of the main advantages of the game is the cooperative mode, which allows you to play with friends or other players online. Taking on friends together adds new layers of interaction and tactical decisions as you must cooperate to survive.

Left 4 Dead 2 also features a Versus mode, where you can play as one of the special infected characters against a team of survivors. This adds new entertainment and a dose of competition to the gameplay.

The graphics in the game, although not the most modern, are still quite high quality and atmospheric. Realistic environmental details and sound effects create a tense and scary atmosphere, making "Left 4 Dead 2" a real horror game on the playing field.

Even though the game has been out for a long time, Left 4 Dead 2 is still popular and actively supported, with many mods and add-ons that enhance the gaming experience and add new features.

Overall, Left 4 Dead 2 is an exciting and tense shooter that offers a great co-op experience with friends. If you love atmospheric games about zombies and team play, then this game definitely deserves your attention.

143297635.review:
Pros:

Unmatched Cooperative Experience: Few games can match the thrill of taking on waves of the undead with a group of friends by your side. Left 4 Dead 2 elevates the cooperative gaming experience to a whole new level. The strategic gameplay, the intense moments, and the shared victories cement the bonds between players, fostering camaraderie like no other game can.

Timeless Gameplay: Despite being released years ago, Left 4 Dead 2's gameplay remains as fresh and exciting as ever. The innovative AI Director ensures that each playthrough feels like a unique challenge, never letting you rest on your laurels. The adrenaline rush from fighting off hordes of infected, escaping crescendo events, and rescuing downed teammates keeps me coming back for more, time and time again.

Immersive World: Valve's attention to detail in creating a post-apocalyptic Southern setting is awe-inspiring. From the eerie, mist-covered swamps to the desolate, crumbling cityscapes, each environment is crafted with love and care, immersing players in a world overrun by chaos. The atmosphere alone is enough to send shivers down your spine.

Dynamic Characters: The diverse cast of survivors are not just cookie-cutter heroes; they are full-fledged personalities with unique backstories and distinct interactions. Whether you're taking the lead as the tough-as-nails Rochelle or playing the wise-cracking Ellis, each survivor brings their flavor to the game, making the experience all the more enjoyable.

Cons:

Roachelle

Yeah, see, he was driving over it late at night and there in the middle of the bridge was what looked like, In Keith's estimation, like a dead bear, so Keith gets out his car to find a stick to poke at it right? Well, it turns out it's just some lady's fur coat that musta fallen out her car, so, hey, free coat, right? Now, owls won't normally attack a man, but in this case, they were hungry, and that made them reckless, man. Keith reckons that they musta been there for hours watchin' what they thought was a bear carcass, 'cause as soon as he picked it up, them owls had claws in him inch deep. Well, Keith figures his best bet is to jump in a lake, 'cause owls can't swim. Well, them owls could. 139337351.review:
If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

6 tablespoons unsalted butter

1/2 cup white sugar

1/2 cup brown sugar

1/4 cup water

1/4 teaspoon cinnamon

1 pinch salt

5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced

1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).

Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.

Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.

Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.

Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.

Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

139226507.review:
Left for dead 2 is a really great, solo or multiplayer, zombie mashing game! Honestly I don't really like zombie games very much, but I really enjoy L4D2 even after playing it for 12 years!

Positives:
- Good solo or multiplay
- Nice variety of game modes so you can play whatever variety of apocalypse you want!
- Servers still active, so there are people to play with still if you have no one local
- Can play online or with friends only, so you can do the versus modes even if there are only two of you

 Negatives:
- Sometimes when playing as a zombie you get stuck places
- Not the most intelligent AI, but also not awful

Honestly I don't have much bad to say about this game, I loved it way back when and I still do. Would recommend.

137876291.review:
[h1]9/10 Atmospheric Masterpeace👑[/h1] 👇

Left 4 Dead 2 really feels like the game that [b]the original should have been[/b]. Even though it was delivered with an astonishing (read: somewhat concerning) turn around time, it ultimately doesn't feel as rushed as the first, offering—with the exception of a still-missing capable single-player component—a solid multiplayer suite that doesn't skimp on modes, maps or options. Versus, Survival, Scavenge and the new Realism mode, which I haven't delved into as much as the other game types, all feature plenty of variety in terms of levels and mode-specific maps.

But if you didn't care for the original Left 4 Dead's brand of multiplayer mayhem, Left 4 Dead 2 won't do much to change your mind. Me? I did care for the original Left 4 Dead, deeply, playing more of that game than any other this year. Left 4 Dead 2 brings with it the same high quality, the same barebones storytelling and, at its core, the same intense competitive and cooperative gameplay. But that gameplay has been heavily tweaked, radically changing and improving the experience for the Left 4 Dead veteran, offering a unique environment in which to get infected all over again. 

[b][i]Left 4 Dead 2's aesthetic, its southern charms, grew on me quickly. The game's better levels offer a horrifying look at the result of mass panic, our four Survivors happening upon a wasteland of deserted cars, downed planes and abandoned homes in the wake of the recently spread infection.[/i] 💗

136979272.review:
If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

6 tablespoons unsalted butter

1/2 cup white sugar

1/2 cup brown sugar

1/4 cup water

1/4 teaspoon cinnamon

1 pinch salt

5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced

1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).

Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.

Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.

Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.

Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.

Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

135455957.review: My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead, murdered by my brother-in-law Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, Hank came to me with a rather, shocking proposition. He asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using his connections in the drug world. Connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded, I... I always thought that Hank was a very moral man and I was... thrown, confused, but I was also particularly vulnerable at the time, something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me on a ride along, and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin so I agreed. Every day, I think back at that moment with regret. I quickly realized that I was in way over my head, and Hank had a partner, a man named Gustavo Fring, a businessman. Hank essentially sold me into servitude to this man, and when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn. Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling out. From what I can gather, Hank was always pushing for a greater share of the business, to which Fring flatly refused to give him, and things escalated. Fring was able to arrange, uh I guess I guess you call it a "hit" on my brother-in-law, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured, and I wound up paying his medical bills which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge, working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring, and did so. In fact, the bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen in the ranks to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA, and about that time, to keep me in line, he took my children from me. For 3 months he kept them. My wife, who up until that point, had no idea of my criminal activities, was horrified to learn what I had done, why Hank had taken our children. We were scared. I was in Hell, I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, to end this nightmare, and in response, he gave me this. I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. I... All I could think to do was to make this video in hope that the world will finally see this man, for what he really is.

I've been playing this for years now. You'd think it would be dead by now, but it's still a brilliant game to play. 

Very responsive if a decent ping (can even play on not so great ping), every time you play a map there will be differences. Team work dynamics are great. still a decent active community. You have a bunch of team killers on the loose on the servers, but you get so used to them that it's become a part of the game. Just have to get them and kick them fast and they are out. In the end you'll get a good full team and have some epic times.

I'd still recommend this game as much as I would have when it was first out. 

Brilliant long lasting highly playable development.
